questions.question: A patient diagnosed with ventricular tachycardia was started on a class1B anti-arrhythmicdrug. Identify the drug.
The additional mechanism by which class 1A drugs additionally prolong action potentialduration is:
questions.explanation: Class IA antiarrhythmics block K+ channels leading to prolongation of action potential duration.The main action of class IA antiarrhythmics is blocking Na + channels causing:• Slowing the upstroke of the action potential• Slowing conduction•Prolonging the QRS duration

questions.question: Which of the following antiarrhythmics has the fastest rate of recovery on Na+ channelblockade?
questions.explanation: Phenytoin and mexiletine which are class IB antiarrhythmic drugs have the fastest rate ofrecovery on Na+ channel blockade.They show the fastest dissociation kinetics to Na+ channel blockade (<1 sec).224ClassIACClassNa+channel blockadeIntermediate- 1-10 seRapid- <1 secPotassium channelSignificant K+channel blockerK+channel openerAction potential durationProlongedShortened or no effectIBClassICSlow->10 secNegligible K+channel blockerVariable or no effectClass | Antiarrhythmic drugsEffect on action potential durationProlonged action potential durationClass IAMAowShortened action potential durationClass IDNo effect on action potential durationClass ICOMARROW

questions.question: Dofetilide belongs to which class of anti-arrhythmic drugs?
questions.explanation: Dofetilide belongs to class III of anti-arrhythmic drugs.

questions.question: An athlete diagnosed with atrial fibrillation was administered an antiarrhythmic drug. Severalhours later, he complains of lower abdominal pain and not having passed urine sinceadmission. Examination reveals a palpable bladder. Which was the most probable drugadministered?
questions.explanation: The given scenario is suggestive of urinary retention. Disopyramide, a class 1A antiarrhythmic isthe drug most likely to cause these symptoms in this patient.It causes prominent anticholinergic side effects like urinary retention, dry mouth, blurred vision,precipitation of glaucoma, and constipation.It is the drug of choice for vagally mediated atrial fibrillation such as sleep-induced or atrialfibrillation in athletes.

questions.question: Which of the following drugs is associated with QT prolongation?
questions.explanation: QT prolongation is seen with quinidine.225It causes torsades de pointes, a life-threatening form of polymorphic ventricular tachycardia.HR:107 IIX2 25511 X2 25mm/s

questions.question: A patient presents with sinus bradycardia and bronchospasm. She was previously diagnosedwith AV nodal reentrant tachycardia and had been started on an antiarrhythmic drug. Whichof the following drugs is most likely being used?
questions.explanation: Propafenone is the most likely drug being used in this patient as sinus bradycardia andbronchospasm are adverse effects seen with the use of this drug.These side effects are due to its weak beta-blocking activity.

questions.question: 217Blurred vision in a patient being treated for paroxysmal supraventricular tachycardia is mostlikely due to:
questions.explanation: Blurred vision is the most common dose-related non-cardiac adverse effect of flecainide therapy.Flecainide is a class 1C antiarrhythmic agent. It acts mainly by sodium channel blockade. It doesnot cause any change in the action potential duration..Flecainide is used in paroxysmal supraventricular tachycardia (PSVTs):Atrioventricular nodal re-entrant tachycardia (AVNRT)• AV re-entrant tachycardia (AVRT)• Atrial fibrillation/atrial flutter (without structural heart disease)

questions.question: Which of the following antiarrhythmics has both class II and class III action?
questions.explanation: Sotalol is a class III antiarrhythmic agent with additional beta-adrenergic blocking effects. (class IIantiarrhythmic action)226Propranolol is a class II antiarrhythmic agent that has an additional Na+ channel blocking effect.(class I antiarrhythmic action)Esmolol is a short-acting beta-blocker with minimal/no action on cardiac Na+ and K+ channels.

questions.question: A patient presented to the ER with dizziness and palpitations. ECG is shown below. Which ofthe following drugs cannot be used in this condition?
questions.explanation: The scenario and ECG findings (absent P waves and RR intervals that are irregularly irregular) aresuggestive of atrial fibrillation. Lignocaine is not used in atrial arrhythmias.Lignocaine is a class 1B anti-arrhythmic agent. It blocks Na+ channels mostly in theclosed/inactivated state. It is not used in atrial arrhythmias because the atrial action potential is soshort that the Na+ channels are in a closed/ inactivated state for only a brief amount of time.Lignocaine is used in the acute treatment of ventricular tachycardia and ventricular fibrillation.Drugs mostly used for supraventricular arrhythmia are:•Adenosine• Verapamil• Diltiazem•DigoxinDrugs used for ventricular arrhythmia are:•⚫ Lidocaine• MexiletineDrugs used in both conditions are:⚫ Amiodarone•• Beta-blockers• Class 1a / 1c antiarrhythmics

questions.question: Which of the following is incorrect regarding lignocaine?

options.C: In heart failure patients, both loading and maintenance doses are decreased
options.D: Indicated for prophylaxis of arryhythmias in all cases of suspected MI

questions.explanation: Lignocaine decreases the incidence of arrhythmias in patients with suspected MI. However,it increases mortality probably by precipitating heart block or congestive heart failure. Hence it isnot routinely used for prophylaxis in MI patients but it is used only when indicated.Gastrointestinal absorption of lignocaine is good but bioavailability is very less due to highfirst-pass hepatic metabolism. Therefore, it is not used through the oral route.Lignocaine has a high volume of distribution. The loading dose is required to achieve rapidaction.In heart failure, both volumes of distribution and clearance are reduced. Both the loading doseand maintenance dose have to be reduced.227

questions.question: Which of the following is a correct statement regarding antiarrhythmics?

options.A: Sotalol has additional class II action
options.B: Esmolol has additional class IV action
options.C: Propranolol has additional class I action.

questions.explanation: Sotalol has both class II (beta-blocker) and class III action (K+ channel blockade). Though it is anonselective beta-blocker, as an antiarrhythmic, it is classified under class III.Propranolol is a non-selective beta-blocker with additional membrane-stabilizing action especiallyat higher doses: Na+ channel blockade/ class I action.Esmolol is a beta 1 selective blocker that does not have any additional class effect.

questions.question: A 60-year-old man presents to the OPD with complaints of bluish discoloration of the skin onthe sun-exposed areas. He has been on medication for monomorphic ventricular tachycardiafor the past 3 years. Which drug is most likely implicated in this condition?
questions.explanation: The scenario is suggestive of blue man syndrome which is most likely caused by amiodarone.One of the side effects of amiodarone is photosensitivity. In some cases, bluish discoloration ofthe skin is seen, predominantly in the sun-exposed areas. This could be due to the immuneresponse in dermal layers by amiodarone or the accumulation of amiodarone in superficial layersof skin.The symptoms are reversible on drug discontinuation. The syndrome is related to both dose andphotosensitivity.The side effects of amiodarone include:• Pulmonary fibrosis•Hypotension, depressed ventricular function•• Torsades de pointes• Corneal microdeposits• Hepatotoxicity• Neuropathies•Photosensitivity.Thyroid dysfunctionOther such syndromes associated with drugs are:• Red man syndrome - Vancomycin•Gray baby syndrome - Chloramphenicol

questions.question: Chronic usage of an antiarrhythmic drug leads to optic neuritis and smurf skin orceruloderma in a patient. Which of the following is not a mechanism of action of this drug?
questions.explanation: Optic neuritis and smurf skin (blueman syndrome or ceruloderma) are caused byamiodarone. It acts by blocking K+, Na+, and Ca2+ channels. It also blocks adrenergic effects. Itdoes not block Cl- channels.228Amiodarone is classified as a class III antiarrhythmic agent. It exerts its function through thefollowing mechanisms:• Blockade of transient outward delayed rectifier and inward rectifier K+ currents• Blockade of inactivated Na+ channels with a rapid rate of recovery• Decreases Ca2+ current•Non-competitive adrenergic blockadeIt is the drug of choice for acute treatment of VT and VF.The side effects of amiodarone include:• Pulmonary fibrosis•Hypotension, depressed ventricular function•• Torsades de pointes• Corneal microdeposits• Hepatotoxicity• Neuropathies••PhotosensitivityThyroid dysfunction

questions.question: Which of the following adverse effects is least likely in a patient who is on chronicamiodarone therapy?
questions.explanation: Nephrotoxicity is not an adverse effect of chronic amiodarone therapy. Pulmonaryfibrosis associated with dry cough is the most serious side effect of chronic amiodarone therapy. Itcan rapidly progress and become fatal.The side effects of amiodarone include:•Pulmonary fibrosis• Hypotension, depressed ventricular function• Torsades de pointes• Corneal microdeposits• Hepatotoxicity••NeuropathiesPhotosensitivity• Thyroid dysfunction

questions.question: Which of the following antiarrhythmic drugs is contraindicated in a patient with interstitiallung disease?
questions.explanation: Amiodarone is contraindicated in a patient with interstitial lung disease.229The most serious adverse effect during chronic amiodarone therapy is pulmonary fibrosis, whichcan be rapidly progressive and fatal. Underlying lung disease, doses of 400 mg/day or more, andrecent pulmonary insults such as pneumonia appear to be risk factors for this condition.Amiodarone is a class III antiarrhythmic drug.The side effects of amiodarone include:• Pulmonary fibrosis• Hypotension, depressed ventricular function• Torsades de pointes•Corneal microdeposits• Hepatotoxicity• Neuropathies••PhotosensitivityThyroid dysfunction

questions.question: Which of the following statements about dronedarone is incorrect?

options.A: It does not contain iodine moiety
options.B: Has stronger antiadrenergic effects than amiodarone
options.C: Less effective antiarrhythmic when compared to amiodarone
options.D: Dose adjustment has to be done in renal failure

questions.explanation: Dronedarone undergoes hepatic metabolism and hence dose adjustment is not required in renalfailure as it is not excreted through the kidneys.Dronedarone is a non-iodinated congener of amiodarone. Like amiodarone, it is a blocker ofmultiple ion channels. It has stronger antiadrenergic effects than amiodarone. It is less effective inmaintaining sinus rhythm and is considered less antiarrhythmic when compared to amiodarone.Unlike amiodarone, it does not cause thyroid dysfunction or pulmonary fibrosis. However, itcauses hepatotoxicity and increases the risk of stroke and heart failure.

questions.question: Given below is the ECG of a patient who presented to the emergency room with sudden onsetpalpitations and breathlessness. Which of the following drugs can be used in this condition?220
questions.explanation: The clinical scenario and the ECG findings are suggestive of paroxysmal supraventriculartachycardia (PSVT). Verapamil and diltiazem are used in both acute treatment and prophylaxis ofPSVT.Their mechanism of action is by slowing SA node automaticity and AV nodal conduction velocity.Additionally, they also decrease cardiac contractility and reduce blood pressure.Dihydropyridines like nifedipine and amlodipine do not have any antiarrhythmic property.Drugs used for supraventricular arrhythmias are:• Adenosine•Verapamil• Diltiazem230•DigoxinDrugs used for ventricular arrhythmias are:• Lidocaine• MexiletineDrugs used in both conditions are:•⚫ Amiodarone• Beta-blockers• Class 1A / 1C antiarrhythmicsTreatment algorithm forParoxysmal supraventricular tachycardiaHemodynamically stableRegular, narrow QRS tachycardiaVagal maneuvers(Carotid sinus massage.Valsalva maneuverTerminationMNo termination/Cannot performIV Adenosine (6-12 mg rapidly)TerminationNo terminationVerapamil/DiltiazemAlternatively: Beta-blockersNo terminationIV Ibutilide + AV nodal blocking agentIV Procainamide AV nodal blocking agentCardioversionMARROWTermination

questions.question: Vernakalant is indicated in which of the following types of arrhythmias?
questions.explanation: Vernakalant is a newer antiarrhythmic agent indicated in atrial fibrillation.Its mechanisms of action include:.• Frequency and voltage-dependent block of the early and late components of the sodium current.• The muscarinic potassium current IKACh, which is constitutively activated in atrial fibrillation isalso blockedIt is indicated for rapid termination of atrial fibrillation in patients with no or minimal structuralheart disease.

questions.question: A patient presented with palpitations and light-headedness. His ECG is shown below. Whichof the following drugs is least likely to cause this condition?221

options.B: DisopyramideProcainamided) LidocaineCourtesy of Jason E. Roediger, CCT, CRATaVRQuestion 21:Which of the following is the drug of choice for the immediate management of a patient withparoxysmal supraventricular tachycardia?a) Verapamilb) Diltiazem

questions.explanation: The given scenario and the ECG findings (rapid asynchronous complexes and an undulatingbaseline) point towards a diagnosis of torsades de pointes. Lidocaine use is unlikely to cause thiscondition.231Lidocaine belongs to class IB antiarrhythmics. It is considered to have the least arrhythmogenicpotential among antiarrhythmics.Among the antiarrhythmics, class Ia and class III drugs prolong action potential duration andthus prolong QT interval. questions.question: A patient who was recently diagnosed with a seizure disorder presents to the casualty withaltered mental status. His ECG shows a prolonged QTc. There is history of sudden cardiacdeaths in his family at an early age. On further evaluation, a diagnosis of congenital long QTsyndrome is made. Which is the most suitable pharmacological agent to treat this condition?
questions.explanation: Hemodynamically stableRegular, narrow QRS tachycardiaVagal maneuvers(Carotid sinus massage.Valsalva maneuver)No termination/Cannot performTerminationIV Adenosine (6-12 mg rapidly)TerminationNo terminationVerapamil / DiltiazemAlternatively: Beta-blockersNo terminationIV Ibutilide +AV nodal blocking agentIV Procainamide AV nodal blocking agentCardioversionOMARROWTermination232Beta-blockers like metoprolol are the mainstay of pharmacological therapy in both asymptomaticand symptomatic patients with congenital LQTS. They reduce both syncope and sudden cardiacdeath (SCD).Long QT syndrome (LQTS) is a disorder of ventricular myocardial repolarization characterized bya prolonged QT interval on the electrocardiogram that can lead to symptomatic ventriculararrhythmias and an increased risk of sudden cardiac death.

questions.question: An elderly patient with heart failure and atrial fibrillation is stabilized with digoxin. By whatmechanism does it control the arrhythmia in this patient?

options.D: Decreasing atrial repolarization by blocking Na+ channels

questions.explanation: Digoxin results in an increased vagal tone which helps in controlling the ventricular rate in atrialfibrillation.Increased vagal tone increases the AV nodal refractoriness due to blockade of Ca2+ channels. Italso results in hyperpolarisation and shortening of atrial action potentials due to activation ofACh-mediated K+ channels in the atria.

questions.question: A male patient who is suffering from a psychotic disorder is on antipsychotic, antidepressantand antihypertensive treatment. He suddenly developed tachycardia and chest tightness. Onevaluation he had metabolic acidosis. ECG showed widened QRS complex and prolonged QTinterval. Which of the following drugs is responsible for this?
questions.explanation: The given clinical scenario is suggestive of torsades de pointes. Only amitriptyline causes thiscondition, among the above drugs.Torsades de pointes (French: twisting of points) is a life-threatening form of polymorphicventricular tachycardia with rapid asynchronous complexes and an undulating baseline on ECG.HR: 107 IIXII X2 25K11 X2 25mm/s233
